Award.AwardTitle: The Impacts of Narratives-based Risk Communication on Hazard Preparedness

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Local hazard preparedness is vital to avoid disaster in the face of extreme events. Whereas conventional risk communication relies on scientific information to affect hazard preparedness, such technical information is often ineffectively assimilated into people's risk perceptions and decisions. Hazard preparedness is largely shaped by factors such as cultural values, cognitive biases, affect, knowledge, information, and experiences, all of which are communicated through stories that people construct and recount to one another. This research will test the effects of an innovative narrative-based risk communication strategy that locates science hazard information in locally produced hazard narratives. Effectively connecting scientific information to individual risk perceptions and decisions through co-produced risk narratives potentially offers an innovative way to improve hazard preparedness that could translate across hazard issues more broadly. With the project focus on flooding events, this research will draw upon expertise in social behavioral sciences, hydrology, and computer science.

This interdisciplinary research effort focuses on testing whether a co-produced, narrative-based risk communication approach is more effective than conventional risk communication at improving hazard preparedness (defined as risk perception and decisions). The first objective is to develop co-produced risk narratives that are both scientifically accurate and locally relevant. Using a community-based participatory research (CBPR) approach, baseline data of flood risk narratives will be collected from river communities to ascertain narrative elements as identified in the Narrative Policy Framework (NPF). Narrative elements include subsets of narrative structure (e.g., use of characters, plot) and narrative content (who is cast in the roles of hero, villain, victim). Whereas narrative structures are stable, content varies across narratives. The characters cast in the narrative and their associated actions are formative in constructing different notions of reality and consequent decisions. Natural Language Processing computational techniques will then be used to identify key narrative content from the CBPR data to obtain the best set of combinations of narrative structure and narrative content situated in local language and images. Subsequently, researchers will quantify, explain, and depict sources of hydrologic uncertainty (data, model, and natural uncertainty) associated with flood frequency analysis in 100-year flood maps for each community. This resulting information will be embedded into the algorithmically enhanced CBPR-based risk narratives to create locally relevant and scientifically accurate flood risk narratives. These risk narratives will be returned to the CBPR groups for adjustment and validation. The second objective focuses on testing the effects of these co-produced risk narratives as narrative treatments on hazard preparedness (i.e., risk perception and intended decisions) with an experimental survey design across the larger population in these river communities. Differently constructed co-produced narratives (i.e., hero-focused, victim-focused, hero & victim focused narratives) will be used as treatments to test the extent to which they influence hazard preparedness in contrast to a non-narrative science statement and a control condition of no treatment. The findings are expected to provide insight into the power of narratives in communicating hazard risk and affecting hazard preparedness. The outcomes are expected to be useful for those local and federal entities involved in hazard preparedness strategies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Local hazard preparedness is vital to avoid disaster in the face of extreme events. Nationwide, the potential for flooding is based on projections of 100-year flood events, but there is seems to be a gap between this information and a concomitant adjustment in hazard preparedness (see Figure 1). Conventional risk communication focuses on sharing scientific information; however, simple diffusion of scientific information rarely affects hazard preparedness. This project utilized an interdisciplinary approach to risk communication by testing an innovative narrative-based risk communication framework. Why narratives? According to the Narrative Policy Framework (NPF), people communicate about and understand their world primarily through narratives; as such, narratives are powerful in shaping opinions and decisions. The innovation of this study is that theoretically  grounded (NPF) and computationally validated risk narratives will be co-developed  with lay citizens and used as treatments to test the extent to which they influence hazard preparedness. Our central research question that guided our project is: Is a co-produced, narrative-based  risk  communication  approach  more  effective  than  conventional  risk  communication  at improving hazard preparedness?

Major Findings: (1) We investigated specific narrative mechanism of use of characters (hero, victim-to-hero, and victim) in risk communication messages. We found that situating the target audience as the hero and victim-to-hero resulted in higher probability of engaging in flood preparation behaviors than conventional messages that contain the language of probability or certainty. As such, narrative-based risk communication is a lingua franca to translate scientific information. (2) We investigated the cognitive processes of how this narrative mechanism works. We found that messages situating the target audience as hero and victim-to-hero resulted in greater affective response (what we say is narrative transportation) than the victim message. This means that messages containing hero language are more engaging than those with victim or science alone. (3) We tested to see if there were different affective responses and behavioral intension responses to two different kinds of science messages: flood risk described in terms of probability and flood risk described in terms of certainty. To our surprise, there was no difference between the two science statements. (4) A qualitative study of two eastern Montana communities explained differences in risk perceptions to be based on residents’ experiences within “an active material world”. In other words, these risk perception differences are less about political or economic differences, but, rather, because of the communities’ embodied experiences with the levees along the banks of their communities. The different experiences with recreation, high waters, and the construction of the levees led to different relationships with flooding, resulting in different risk perceptions. (5) Our methods of developing test messages using interview data and natural language processing is an advancement for continued work in testing narrative risk communication. We are publishing our mixed methods procedure in order to bring transparency to the study of narrative risk communication.

Intellectual Merit: (1) This project tested a novel and potentially transformative risk communication framework. Effectively connecting scientific information to individual risk perceptions and decisions through Co-Produced Risk Narratives potentially offers an innovative way to improve hazard preparedness that could translate across hazard issues more broadly. (2) This project used a unique interdisciplinary research approach for addressing this transdisciplinary research question. Whereas existing research on risk and on hazard preparedness includes impressive bodies of discipline-centered scholarship, this project integrated expertise across multiple scientific fields: SBE (political science, environmental economics), GEO (human geography, hydrology) and CSE (computer science). (3) Theoretical advances in each discipline are integral to this proposal: inclusion of narrative elements as a class of variables in hazard preparedness; using economic valuation techniques to measure decisional outcomes from different narrative treatments; testing the interaction between risk perceptions and intended decisions; conveying uncertainties in existing flood mapping; and using computer science techniques to measure and aid in the improvement of narratives.

Broader Impacts: (1) This project created enduring collaborations with the scientific community in Montana of those working on reducing flood risk: local flood managers, NOAA, and US ACOE. We presented out findings to these groups and engaged in flood awareness days in Eastern Montana. (2) This project integrated diversity by providing educational and training opportunities for women in STEM through active recruitment of women and underrepresented graduate students, participation of a STEM woman in the project, and project leadership by a woman social scientist.
